content: On October 29, House and Senate appropriators announced a conference agreement on H.R. 3289, a bill providing supplemental appropriations for military operations in Iraq and Afghanistan. The bill was approved by the House and Senate, and signed into law by the President on November 6. The conference agreement rejected a Senate proposal for Iraq reconstruction assistance to be provided as loans. The President had requested an additional $87 billion for reconstruction assistance and military operations in Iraq and Afghanistan. During congressional consideration of the request for reconstruction aid in Iraq, a wide range of legislative proposals were debated, including measures to address costs, burden sharing, and other issues. These proposals included requiring reports on Iraq policy, encouraging allied contributions, transferring control of reconstruction from the Defense Department to the State Department, and ensuring fair competition on contracts. The debate in Congress focused on providing Iraq reconstruction funds as grants or loans. The $87 billion requested by the Administration included $65.6 billion for defense and $21.4 billion for foreign policy programs. Of the defense funding, $51.5 billion was for ongoing military operations in Iraq, $10.5 billion for U.S. forces in Afghanistan, and $3.6 billion for homeland defense and support to allies. For foreign policy programs, $20.3 billion was allocated for security and reconstruction in Iraq.
